JAR8ofyivMix8_3s9fE-4g.text: Thai cuisine on its highest level!!! I strongly recommend this restaurant!I had the "slow braised beef in aromatic coconut reduction with fresh lime, lemongrass and chilli " with sticky rice: a delicious treat! My friend went for the"yellow coconut curry with New Zealand lamb, new potatoes and baby onions" and was very delighted about her dish as well. The range of wines from all over the world is impressive (starting with about £ 17 per bottle - as far as I remember). We went for a fruity rosé wine from Thailand which was a very good choice!The ambience of the restaurant is stylish and traditional but not to cold. The service is proficient but warmhearted.The bill for two main courses, a side dish, one bottle of wine, one bottle of water and two thai teas totaled £ 83 (service included).

jwoD9nUsct9c6Dwz6xBapw.text: Ingredients seem to be high quality, but the green curry is def on the sweeter side of the spectrum, to the point of overpowering the other flavors. I usually like to try at least a couple of dishes before review, but sugary Thai food isn't my cup of tea. Nice ambiance though.

NZOLygaJfQZ3IcqXKnGG2A.text: Is this my favourite Thai in London? Yes. These fine folks at Patara know what they're doing and they know how to do it well. From the great service quality all the way down to the amazing selection and taste of the food. I've been here with a wide range of groups and have taken friends and clients a like, all with the same reaction, "AMAZING!" While the location is in the middle of Soho and toursity central, it's worth pushing through the confused masses and getting to this little gem of a restaurant on Greek Street!

1JqhO4EFG1E9qx1G7EV8Hw.text: Solid Thai for the area. But surprised to see it was best in this region of london. However, it was VERY reasonably priced. And I praise their vegetarian menu.

ujUiUhIqGWZKFOKOgr_52Q.text: It's interesting to read other reviewers issues with the service at Patara, as when I went last night I thought the service was fine. My boyfriend and I were put into a quiet corner which was nice and we were served promptly even though it was still quite busy at 9.30pm.The food was really very good and I was pleased that they did coconut rice  my favourite. I had the green curry which was tasty  although I'm not convinced it was worth the price tag. However, my boyfriend had the deep fried sea bass in light red curry sauce which was excellent  and exciting as it is a dish we haven't come across in London before.The actual restaurant is visually interesting and the ambience was bustling and generally enticing. Overall I would say this is a great experience, but perhaps a little overpriced.

B9FAWrW0tAfPpLga9MXQRQ.text: I got the lunch special deal, and in it I got the spring rolls and the thai style fried noodles (pad thai). when the spring rolls came there were 5 spring rolls! They were pretty good. Then the pad thai came and it was average.

6qiqHot3QHl-Xx2QajOzNA.text: Hands down the fanciest Thai restaurant I've ever been to in my life. Portions for most of the dishes were on the small side (from what my friends ordered). However, the Nua Tom Kati was by far the most filling dish on the table with several large chunks of beef. It was so filling in fact, that even after sharing a couple pieces, I still wanted to share more! Flavors here were very different than other Thai restaurants I've been to. Meats were really fresh tasting and unprocessed (you know how sometimes you'll eat meat at an Asian restaurant and it doesn't take like how it normally does when you cook it yourself). Vegetables and garnishes were really fresh as well.

G_KDUi3QEusPKLHROSEDUw.text: I'm giving 3 stars because while the food was excellent (my duck with roasted pineapple: to die for), service-wise the rating would be 1.5 stars would be pushing it. Twice, they brought the wrong food to the table. The first time it was corrected (but took forever), and the second time, they just never brought the replacement dish. They were busy, but not overly so, for 9:30 on a Friday night. Everything was slow, and for two people it took us well over 2 hours to get out. Not impressed at all. I'd still go back for the food, just wouldn't expect much from the staff.

AQxK_7aanL0Vq3Ruaz731w.text: The food and service at Patara have been consistently excellent. I've been three or four times, with different friends, and always tried different dishes. Last week i tried the seabass and tom you soup - both really really good. Patara is my new favorite Thai place in London.

7tshutgfHNri7ySyxgO8Wg.text: I've really struggled to find absolutely-blow-your-mind awesome Thai food in London.  There are quite a few cheap-and-good places, and I'm quite partial to Addie's in Earl's Court, but finding that special place has been a hard task.On top of this, I'm usually ver sceptical about Asian fine dining (excluding Japanese) - my last experience had been Plum Valley in Chinatown which, while pretty decent, really didn't do more for me than a normal Chinese restaurant.  Sure, it's nice to have something different, plus you know that the ingredients are probably not Grade Q (for questionable, or something), but it's not usually worth the mark up that comes with it.  That said, Thai food - in my mind - lends itself to fine dining more readily than Chinese; generally speaking, I find the dishes have more colour and aromatic complexity, and after reading some of the lovely reviews from you guys, I decided this was worth the shot.  Hey, if things go badly, it's on ALL YOUR HEADS.  GUARANTEED.They've really gone all out on the interior and for the most part err on the side of not tacky (the replica Buddhist temple in the centre does push that boundary though).  Either way, it's a decent space and doesn't come with the same packed-like-a-nuclear-bunker feeling that some of the restaurants in the same area do.For starter, we had the green mango salad with soft shell crab, betel-wrapped prawns and beef, and tuna tartare.  The first thing I noticed were the generous portions - hey, you get quite a lot for your money, which I don't always expect in places like this.  There were two large bits of soft shell crab which were excellent - the batter wasn't too thick, and the crab itself wasn't mushy as it often is.  There could've been a little more salad, but hey.  The betel-wrapped goodies were pleasant too - the beef was amazingly juicy, and the leaves didn't totally dominate the flavour.  The leaves don't go as well with the prawns, but it was still good.  The fusion-y tuna tartare was ok - fresh fish, and nice lemongrass garnish - but the flavour combination is a bit weak compared to other preparations (especially Japanese/French ones).The mains were similarly of impressive size: we went for the braised beef in coconut, lime, lemongrass, and chilli; the Panang Lamb Shank curry; the sugar snap peas with prawns and mushrooms; and lastly, some pineapple rice.  The braised beef was all manner of cheesy words, but I'mma go for sumptuous.  Ok, so it wasn't *quite* falling apart, but the flavours in the dish are excellent - I especially liked the little bits of lime left in the sauce which give each mouthful a little tangy lift as a great contrast to the creamy, saturated fat (aka coconut milk) sauce.  The Panang curry needs no introduction on this thread either, and totally lived up to its billing - I was just sad that I couldn't pick up the bone, and gnaw every last bit off it (and suck out the marrow).  The veg was good too - just the right amount of crunch.  The pineapple rice was ok...at its heart, it reminded me of kedgeree, but it lacked a little something to make it extra special.So, why 4 stars?  As good as this place is (and, although pricier than most Thai food, gives you a lot for your money, unlike most fine dining places these days...), I just thought that the spice levels were REALLY tame.  I understand that the chefs don't want to drown the complexity of the dishes with chilli, and that they have to cater to their audience, but for me they've just reduced the spice too much.  Even the chilli garnishes have a meagre Scoville rating...I'm guessing that you can probably request more chilli, but to completely ignore part of what makes Thai food Thai food is kind of heinous in my eyes.With that said, I still look forward to coming back here - there's no denying that the dishes are REALLY flavourful, and totally worth the extra over your average Thai.  Just sneak some sliced Bird's Eyes in with you.

nZ529ZGk3oin35U9NVJKOQ.text: Our concierge sent us to Patara as I was craving Thai Food. We loved every dish. We started with kong nueng ruam (assorted dumplings with prawn, chicken and pork fillings). Very tasty. Next we had peek gai sod sai (Golden chicken wings with crisp lemongrass and kaffir lime). I asked for a chicken and basil very spicy and wow did I get it. It was super spicy as I requested. I was craving it days later. If you are in the Knightsbridge area and craving Thai, this is a great spot. Expensive, but worth it.

E78ZpdgJHmpSJk2_7_YOCA.text: The reservation system was quick and easy to use. The Thai food here was Ahhmazing!!! My husband and I started with Kamon Bueng DIY. Do-It-Yourseft Thai tacos of chicken and prawn with cucumber tomato salad. They were delicious and fast! For my main course I tried the Kiew Wan with chicken and it was SERIOUSLY the best I've ever had...My husband had the Nua Prig Thai Dum and it was perfectly peppered and very tasty as well. This place is a hot spot and highly recommended for anyone looking for great service and fantastic Thai food.

Ke9_EWNd8d3wgnnHSDq9kg.text: The food was excellent, subtle and delicious. The service was nice and the ambiance was lovely. We had mango salad with soft-shell crab appetizer which was the best thing. I thought they were a bit stingy on the mango salad and I would have liked more, split between 2 people. We also had lamb and prawns wrapped in betel leaves. This appetizer was well-done but not really my taste. I would skip this one next time. For main course we had white rice with Chicken and bamboo shoots green curry which was very good (a little salty but I have very low salt tolerance). We also had a slow braised beef dish with hints of lime, chili and pineapple that was amazing. That was subtle, creative and delicious. It is a bit pricey. A meal for 2 with drinks came to 80GBP.

tchjHTDJkEefBqKpt2v8Qg.text: Absolutely fantastic Thai food in Soho.  One of my colleagues recommended Patara for a team dinner, and we were all thrilled with our food.  Every single dish was fantastic and the presentation was beautiful!

FNQ8JzA0dUqjFG-AVpPReA.text: Outstanding. Went here on our trip to London from the US last month, and it might possibly be the best Thai food we've ever had. The curry lamb dish was amazing, with great presentation. Mildly pricey, but highly recommended.

_C27Ch355uBGTj1lwH0phQ.text: After Bryan Y.'s review of the Lamb Shank, hey, the word frickin really is a convincing word in my dictionary... I just had to go here and try it out for myself for a little comparison study.  Well kids, this place IS the real deal.  Hands down the best Thai food I've ever eaten and I've eaten at other "fine" thai restaurants before.  My satay trio appetizer was cooked to perfection, sauce lovely.  Next came that fall off the bone Lamb Shank curry.  WOWZA, it was delicious, and it was not only I that thought so either, my 2 dining partners both tried it too and were then not so in love with their dishes (though they did like theirs very much too).  Mmm mmm, slow roasted lamb with a lovely penang peanut curry sauce, really I have no doubt that I will be back here again and ordering the same thing (and me knows my accompanying dinner will be ordering the same too).Sure it's on the pricey side for Thai, and I warn you it will kill your love for that tiny cheap Thai place around your corner, but trust me, both are worth the expense!  Enjoy, enjoy, enjoy people, you only live once and out of this world Thai cuisine awaits you here at Patara!

C-SK0EzedFY1H55egWBy9g.text: The food was good. We had two dishes - one a rice noodle stirfry with king prawns which was a 'chef recommended' dish - this was delicious - but I wouldn't say anything particularly special. The second dish was a type of red curry - this was a tofu dish but we wanted to replace the tofu with prawns. They were pretty accommodating and this wasnt a problem. although the second dish was absolutely delicious, it was quite small and there was more prawn than actual curry. In regards to the service, it didnt start off well....we were waiting almost 20 mins after being seated, before someone came to take our order - and she was pretty grumpy to say the least! However the service after that was fast and all other waitresses and waiters were much more friendly!

9MCuoX8S7vAWg1F-0xZKaA.text: Last night I went to Patara for my first time as fellow yelpers have spoken so fondly  of it I thought I would take it for a spin. I invited 5 of my mates and to a person we were thinking "Yummy in our Tummies" as the food was mouth watering...I actually thought there was a New Years eve fireworks display going off in my mouth.I totally recommend Patara Soho to anyone that loves Thai and wants to chill with some friends and enjoy some fab foodies.

uVqTVpTUihBi-5v9p_gIHg.text: Wonderful, great service, the smells hit you as soon as you walked in. It is on the pricey end of the scale, but worth it for a special occasion.

OMHlay-1xCFTNPy_fuq5Yg.text: Apparently we're all wrong - Patara is the best Thai restaurant in The World. So it's time we forgot about our personal favourite local gems or that street stall when we were in Chiang Mai... the powers have decreed and Patara wins.Patara Bangkok has won best Thai restaurant in Thailand for the last two years and the good news for London is that the Pataras here have virtually the identical menu, ambiance, service levels and cocktails of their little sister in SE Asia. I say little sister because London's Pataras came first... Mayfair, Chelsea and then here in Soho.. before they then headed to the homeland to win their world prize. Think of Patara as our homegrown champion.This Soho Patara is my favourite in London, and runs close to the dining mansion that they have in Bangkok. The interior in the depths below Greek Street is gorgeous, with a beautiful intricate model of the Thai Royal Palace as the worthy centrepiece. I only wish they had their own Tuk-Tuk like they do in Thong Lor.The cocktails are crafted by their award-winning barman on Maddox St and a worth a visit but let's be honest you're here for the food, and it won't disappoint. Rammed full of flavour, presented with artistic beauty and the finest quality through and through - it's easily worth the double or even triple cost compared to your local Thai, heck... it's even worth the 15-times cost compared to the Bangkok streetfood.::: and why is it so good? :::1. Real Thai, not fusion - Authentic dishes, true recipes, no compromise on cooking style, fish sauces or hot spice levels (warning!)2. The best ingredients money can buy - Not beef curry, but veal osso bucco curry. Not seafood and lime spicy salad but smoked salmon and pomelo spicy salad.3. Perfection - classic dishes endlessly studied by the chefs, worked on and improved until nirvana.It's an amazing methodical approach to get the best Thai food on Earth, and strangely behind it all is a mega corporate company called S&P, who seem to be the Thai equivalent of the Marks and Spencer food section. I guess they decided they could afford a wonderful little pet project....

J6U2TtOQ_QLprY-FwukLUg.text: I was sort of... dreading going here. Please no more expensive, watered-down Thai food. Please no more carved vegetable flowers. Please no more mood lighting. And for god sake PLEASE no more small portions that leave me hungry on the bus home. Patara soothed me with it's... mood lighting, then brought me the kind of food that assured me that (minus carved vegetable flowers and the aforementioned mood lighting) all my wishes would be granted.I started with the Srangwah Hoy Shell (poached scallops) and not only we're they actually spicy, they were the best scallops I have ever had in my life. So well cooked and well seasoned. I also got to try some of the Miang Guaytiew (fresh rice paper rolls) and they were really good too! Really good! Even the completely ridiculous sounding "Do-It-Yourself Thai tacos" were tasty and well spiced. What is going on Patara? You were meant to offer me a few curries and some bland spring rolls in oddly shaped dishes, not perfectly executed SPICY FLAVOURFUL food!My main course was a slight let down, I had Gai Yang Kamin (grilled chicken and chilli dip) which came on skewers and was incredibly tender, but so unbelievably sweet I was unable to finish it. I asked for it with Som Tum, which wasn't spicy enough and only okay. The sticky rice was good. I also got to try (a lot) of the Nua Tom Kat (slow braised beef) which was a total five star dish. Zesty, meaty and flavourful and a huge portion!We finished with a mango sticky rice which we all shared, it was presented nicely and was very good. I left surprised, happy and very, very full.

OPxjEM3fSj5Vx__fq7uEyQ.text: Mouth-watering prawn pad thai! The best in london!

0ISt1qpIQRFzEplMfKA6fg.text: I stumbled upon this gem of a Thai restaurant when my cousin and I were exploring London and had just left Harrods.I have to admit...I am a huge fan of Pad Thai and other American, basic noodle dishes that have no spice. I am NOT a fan of spice, and the only reason I am deducting a star for this review is that my dish was quite spicy, despite the menu indicating otherwise. I had the Gai Pad Khing (chicken with mushrooms, onion and pineapple). The ingredients tasted so fresh and perfectly cooked. My cousin had the scallops which came with the 2 or 3 spicy star warning on the menu, so I did not try them. I had a glass of white wine. I was a little underwhelmed by it, but probably just a poor choice. There were a decent amount of wines by the glass. My cousin had one of the teas they offered.This place was packed during lunch time and by the time we left there was a wait. I definitely do not wonder why!

4MPDMqfm3Wd49FT4Zx5BTQ.text: I would say that this is one of the best Thai restaurants in London. The restaurant is very nice, the staff is super friendly and the food is amazing. The prices are ok for the quality. I would recommend booking a table as this restaurant can get busy.

Ewy590VcUOMaHeZiGamOsQ.text: The food was a-mazing, the personnel was very friendly and the service was quick. Although it was a bit too crowded and noisy (we were sitting at a table in the middle of the restaurant), the atmosphere was great and the interior design creates a relaxed and zen feeling. Reservation by telephone or website is recommended.
